question: Question_02_(a)
statement:
Suppose z = f(x,y) has continuous second order partial derivatives and x
= r cos(t), y = r sin(t). Express the following partial derivatives in
terms of r,t and the partial derivatives of f.

 a)

\[\frac{\partial z}{\partial t}\]
sols:
The variable \emph{z} is a function of both \emph{x}, \emph{y} which, in
turn, are both functions of \emph{t}. Thus, any change in \emph{z} in
response to a change in \emph{t} will be the result of how \emph{x} and
\emph{y} change with \emph{t}. We can write the derivative of \emph{z}
with respect to \emph{t} using the chain rule:

\[\frac{\partial z}{\partial t} = \frac{\partial f}{\partial x}\frac{\partial x}{\partial t} + \frac{\partial f}{\partial y}\frac{\partial y}{\partial t}\]
We evaluate the partial derivatives of \emph{x}, \emph{y} with respect
to \emph{t}:

\[\frac{\partial x}{\partial t} = -r \sin(t), \quad \frac{\partial y}{\partial t} = r \cos(t).\]
And thus,

\[{\color{blue}\frac{\partial z}{\partial t} = \frac{\partial f}{\partial x}\cdot (-r \sin(t)) + \frac{\partial f}{\partial y} \cdot r \cos(t)}.\]
hints: To evaluate this partial derivative we need to use the chain rule.
